Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 

1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia

The ammonia refrigeration process at the Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. The ammonia process contains a total charge of approximately 39,000 (LBS). It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 

1.4 Five Year Accident History

Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry has had two (2) accidental release within the last five (5) years.

Incident Investigation # 2014-01
Date of incident: September 23, 2014
Accident duration: 15 minutes
Regulated substance released: Anhydrous Ammonia
Estimated quantity released: 2,700 lbs.
NAICS: 311615
Source: Anhydrous Ammonia release through a relief valve
Weather conditions: 68 degree F and calm
Onsite impacts: 34 injuries
Offsite impacts: None
Initiating event and contributing factors:
The West Relief Valve on the Intercooler (PRV-11A) lifted and remained lifted for approximately 15 minutes.  This was due to a high level conditi

on within the Intercooler (IC-1), which was caused by a faulty solenoid valve (LFSV-IC1) spring.
Offsite responders notified and responded
Recommendations:
Operating Procedures
Additional Training
Engineering Changes

Incident Investigation # 2016-01
Date of incident: May 2, 2016
Accident duration: 46 minutes
Regulated substance released: Anhydrous Ammonia
Estimated quantity released: 1,538 lbs.
NAICS: 311615
Source: Anhydrous Ammonia release through failed Sporlan MA-17 liquid injection oil cooling solenoid valve on Compressor 7
Weather conditions: 86 degree F
Onsite impacts: 5 injuries
Offsite impacts: None
Initiating event and contributing factors:
Failed liquid cooling solenoid valve on Compressor 7. The failure appears to be the result of metal fatigue or a manufacture defect.
Offsite responders notified and responded
Recommendations:
Emergency Notification Checklist Update.
Replace the failed Sporlan MA-17 liquid injection oil cooling solenoid valve on Compressor 7.

3. Incident Investigation # 2016-03
Date of incident: July 24, 2016
Accident duration: 9 minutes
Regulated substance released: Anhydrous Ammonia
Estimated quantity released: 187 lbs.
NAICS: 311615
Source: Anhydrous Ammonia release through Intercooler Pressure Relief Valve.
Weather conditions: 84 degree F
Onsite impacts: 4 injuries
Offsite impacts: None
Initiating event and contributing factors:
Overpressurization in the Intercooler. The overpressurization appears to be the result of deficient supply of city water and power outages due to neighboring facility fire.
Offsite responders notified and responded
Recommendations:
Determine the root cause of the relief valve lifting.
Remove the Intercooler (IC-1) from the refrigeration system.

1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan
Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:
- California Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR §3220

- Federal Emergency Action Plan - Title 29 CFR §1910.38

Strategically, we will respond minimally to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 
Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.

1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.
Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.

1. Executive Summary

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR §68
- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR §5189
- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR §1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a living document. As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 

1.1 Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry, Risk and Process Safety Management Program

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry has updated their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 

Process Name                 | Process Chemical                | Process Quantity(lbs.)
CST Ammonia Refrigeration      Anhydrous Ammonia                 39,000

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses and physical property damage.
1. Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 
2. Prepared a unified program b

ased on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well
3. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)

The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.

1.2 Process Descriptions

Sanger Poultry operates a processing plant and freezer for poultry products that utilizes one (1) ammonia refrigeration system.
The CST Ammonia Refrigeration process provides refrigeration capacity to the following areas:
Cooler
(2) Freezers
Staging Area
Air Chill Room
43ºF Processing Room
70ºF Processing Room

The CST Ammonia Refrigeration process is equipped with air-cooling evaporators and pump recirculators as required for pumped overfeed operation. All control valve groups are mounted on the roof to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within the refrigeration machinery room or directly outside near the machinery room. A partial list of system components includes:
(1) 84 Dia x 13'-9 Long +10ºF Recirculator with (2) Integral Teikoku Ammonia Pumps
(1) 60 Dia x 12'-9 Long -20ºF Recirculator with (2) Integral Teikoku Ammonia Pumps
(1) 84 Dia x 21'-10 High Pressure Receiver
(1) 30 Dia x 5'-7 Long Liquid Subcooler
(1) 42 Dia x 10'-0 Long Suction Accumulator
(1) 20 Dia x 3'-4 Long Liquid Transfer Vessel
(1) 30 Dia x 9'-0 Long Thermosyphon Receiver
(1) 7'-3 Dia x 18' Long Ammonia Diffusion Tank
(2) Frick XLP2-1236-2036 Evaporative Condensers
(1) Frick RWF II-316 600 HP Screw Compressor
(1) Frick RWF II-100 200 HP Screw Compressor
(1) Frick RWF II-222 437 HP Screw Compressor
(1) Frick RWF II-270 643 HP Screw Compressor
(2) Frick RWF II-270 600 HP Screw Compressors
(1) Machinery Room Ventilation System
(6) Penthouse Evaporators
(2) Ceiling Suspended Evaporators
(16) Air Ch

ill Coils
(4) AcuAir Units with Integral Surge Drums

The CST Ammonia Refrigeration process operates as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped through a liquid feed solenoid valve, an expansion valve, and into a liquid recirculator.  From there, low pressure liquid is pumped to each evaporator, where it passes through a solenoid valve, hand expansion valve and into evaporator.  Low temperature liquid circulates through the evaporator.  As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which passes through an isolation valve and is returned to the liquid recirculator.  The residual liquid is separated from the gas in the recirculator and the gas is piped to the main suction accumulator and then the suction inlet on the compressors which elevate the temperature and pressure of the gas.  The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to a water cooled evaporative condenser where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to the high pressure receiver.

The refrigeration system was built in 2015-2016 by Cold Storage Technologies. The system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and pressure relief valves which vent ammonia gas to a diffusion tank if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point. Each entrance to a machinery room contains emergency refrigeration shutdown and ventilation controls for use during an emergency situation.

The CST Ammonia Refrigeration process at Sanger Poultry consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. As such, Sanger Poultry has one (1) refrigeration process.

1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

1.3.1 General 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. Duri

Through the RMP-PSM program Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
